predictit.data_preprocessing module¶

Module for data preprocessing. Contain functions for removing outliers, NaN columns or data smoothing. If you want to see how functions work - working examples with printed results are in tests - visual.py.

Default output data shape is (n_samples, n_features)

All processing funtions after data_consolidation use numpy.ndarray with ndim == 2, so reshape(1, -1) if necessary.

predictit.data_preprocessing.data_consolidation(data, config)[source]¶

Input data in various formats and shapes and return data in defined shape, that other functions rely on.

Parameters

data (np.ndarray, pd.DataFrame) – Input data in well standardized format.

Raises

KeyError, TypeError – If wrong configuration in configuration.py. E.g. if predicted column name not found in dataframe.

Returns

Data in standardized form.

Data array for prediction - predicted column on index 1, and column for ploting as pandas dataframe.

Return type

np.ndarray, pd.DataFrame, str

predictit.data_preprocessing.do_difference(data)[source]¶

Transform data into neighbor difference. For example from [1, 2, 4] into [1, 2].

Parameters

dataset (ndarray) – Numpy on or multi dimensional array.

Returns

Differenced data.

Return type

ndarray

Examples

>>> data = np.array([1, 3, 5, 2])
>>> print(do_difference(data))
[2, 2, -3]
predictit.data_preprocessing.fitted_power_transform(data, fitted_stdev, mean=None, fragments=10, iterations=5)[source]¶

Function mostly for data postprocessing. Function transforms data, so it will have similiar standar deviation, similiar mean if specified. It use Box-Cox power transform in SciPy lib.

Parameters

  • data (np.array) – Array of data that should be transformed.

  • fitted_stdev (float) – Standard deviation that we want to have.

  • mean (float, optional) – Mean of transformed data. Defaults to None.

  • fragments (int, optional) – How many lambdas will be used in one iteration. Defaults to 9.

  • iterations (int, optional) – How many iterations will be used to find best transform. Defaults to 4.

Returns

Transformed data with demanded standard deviation and mean.

Return type

np.array

predictit.data_preprocessing.inverse_difference(differenced_predictions, last_undiff_value)[source]¶

Transform do_difference transform back.

Parameters

  • differenced_predictions (ndarray) – One dimensional!! differenced data from do_difference function.

  • last_undiff_value (float) – First value to computer the rest.

Returns

Normal data, not the additive series.

Return type

ndarray

Examples

>>> data = np.array([1, 1, 1, 1])
>>> print(inverse_difference(data, 1))
[2, 3, 4, 5]
predictit.data_preprocessing.keep_corelated_data(data, predicted_column_index=0, threshold=0.5)[source]¶

Remove columns that are not corelated enough to predicted columns.

Parameters

  • data (np.array, pd.DataFrame) – Time series data.

  • predicted_column_index (int, optional) – Column that is predicted. Defaults to 0.

  • threshold (float, optional) – After correlation matrix is evaluated, all columns that are correlated less than threshold are deleted. Defaults to 0.2.

Returns

Data with no columns that are not corelated with predicted column.

Return type

np.array, pd.DataFrame

predictit.data_preprocessing.load_data(config)[source]¶
predictit.data_preprocessing.preprocess_data(data_for_predictions, predicted_column_index=0, multicolumn=0, remove_outliers=False, smoothit=False, correlation_threshold=False, data_transform=False, standardizeit=False)[source]¶
predictit.data_preprocessing.preprocess_data_inverse(data, final_scaler=None, last_undiff_value=None, standardizeit=False, data_transform=False)[source]¶
predictit.data_preprocessing.remove_the_outliers(data, predicted_column_index=0, threshold=3)[source]¶

Remove values far from mean - probably errors. If more columns, then onlyu rows that have outlier on predicted column will be deleted.

Parameters

  • data (np.array) – Time series data. Must have ndim = 2, if univariate, reshape…

  • predicted_column_index (int, optional) – Column that is predicted. Defaults to 0.

  • threshold (int, optional) – How many times must be standard deviation from mean to be ignored. Defaults to 3.

Returns

Cleaned data.

Return type

np.array

Examples

>>> data = np.array([[1, 3, 5, 2, 3, 4, 5, 66, 3]])
>>> print(remove_the_outliers(data))
[1, 3, 5, 2, 3, 4, 5, 3]
predictit.data_preprocessing.smooth(data, window=101, polynom_order=2)[source]¶

Smooth data (reduce noise) with Savitzky-Golay filter. For more info on filter check scipy docs.

Parameters

  • data (ndarray) – Input data.

  • window (tuple, optional) – Length of sliding window. Must be odd.

  • - Must be smaller than window. (polynom_order) –

Returns

Cleaned data with less noise.

Return type

ndarray

predictit.data_preprocessing.split(data, predicts=7, predicted_column_index=0)[source]¶

Divide data set on train and test set.

Parameters

  • data (pandas.DataFrame, ndarray) – Time series data.

  • predicts (int, optional) – Number of predicted values. Defaults to 7.

  • predicted_column_index (int, optional) – Index of column that is predicted. Defaults to 0.

Returns

Train set and test set.

Return type

ndarray, ndarray

Examples

>>> data = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4])
>>> train, test = (split(data, predicts=2))
>>> print(train, test)
[2, 3]
[4, 5]
predictit.data_preprocessing.standardize(data, used_scaler='standardize', predicted_column=0)[source]¶

Standardize or normalize data. More standardize methods available.

Parameters

  • data (ndarray) – Time series data.

  • used_scaler (str, optional) – ‘01’ and ‘-11’ means scope from to for normalization. ‘robust’ use RobustScaler and ‘standard’ use StandardScaler - mean is 0 and std is 1. Defaults to ‘standardize’.

Returns

Standardized data.

Return type

ndarray
